I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $70,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) to Citic Financial Leasing Co. Ltd. (CFL) for the Solar 
Energy Finance Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The project entails the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing long-tenor financing to 
CFL for lease finance to solar power plants (SPPs) for solar energy generation in the PRC. ADB 
financing will meet CFL’s requirements for long-term funding, which is in short supply in the PRC, 
and will enable CFL to provide long-tenor lease finance to SPPs. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  Solar power overview. The PRC has been the world’s largest greenhouse gas (GHG) 
emitter since 2007.1 It produced 9.22 billion tons of carbon dioxide in 2017, equivalent to 28% of 
global  carbon  dioxide  emissions.2 In  September  2016,  the  PRC  officially  joined  the  Paris 
Agreement after completing the domestic legislative process, signifying its commitment to fight 
global warming and reduce GHGs under a measurable target. The government has boosted 
support for investment in renewable energy, mainly in solar and wind power projects. Key support 
measures include (i) the legal framework for a 20-year feed-in tariff (FIT), which is not subject to 
retrospective application of price changes; (ii) a centrally planned, newly installed capacity 
program governed by the National Energy Association; and (iii) a government fund that subsidizes 
the grid company to take on part of the FIT obligation for the electricity generation companies. 
 
4.  Electricity generated from solar photovoltaic assets has grown rapidly from 29 terawatt-
hours in 2014 to 131 terawatt-hours in 2017.3 As of year-end (YE) 2018, the PRC’s solar power 
generation capacity reached 174 gigawatts (GW), a 34% increase from 2017, and accounted for 
24% of the 728 GW installed renewable energy capacity. As the cost of solar photovoltaic energy 
has decreased significantly because of increased economies of scale and enhanced technology, 
the government will remove renewable energy generation subsidies in 2020. However, this policy 
change will not have an impact on existing solar power assets in operation, which will continue to 
benefit from the FIT scheme at the start of plant operation. Subsidy removal will also have limited 
impact on new solar photovoltaic projects, as such assets will be designed to reach an acceptable 
rate of return without relying on subsidies. In 2019, the government approved the first grid-parity 
solar photovoltaic project list, with nearly 15 GW capacity. Significant investment must continue 
to be made in renewable energy projects to meet the government’s commitment to fight climate 
change and pursue environmentally sustainable development. It is expected that 20–50 GW of 
solar photovoltaic energy generation capacity will be installed each year from 2019 to 2050. 
Coupled with the retirement and replacement of solar modules, large continuous investment in 
new solar power generation assets will be required, creating vast financing needs. 
 
5.  Leasing industry overview. Leasing provides a good solution for long-term solar power 
equipment financing as banks usually do not recognize movable assets, such as equipment, as 
collateral. The PRC’s leasing industry has been growing rapidly, targeting a financing gap that

traditional bank financing does not address. New leasing sales in the PRC expanded from 
$21.88 billion in 2008 to $265.68 billion in 2017, representing a compound annual growth rate of 
31.97%.4 Despite rapid growth, the PRC’s financial leasing industry needs further development. 
The PRC’s lease penetration rate, measured as a percentage of lease finance to total gross 
domestic product, was 2.21% in 2017, ranking it 12th out of 50 countries and indicating ample 
room for growth. With total outstanding lease receivables of CNY6.55 trillion in 2018, leasing is 
also much smaller than banking, which had total outstanding loans of CNY108.56 trillion in 2018 
(footnote 4). 
 
6.  Rationale. ADB’s nonsovereign operations have supported leasing in the PRC—targeting 
a diverse range of development subsectors—given its underdevelopment and need for long-tenor 
financing. ADB has provided $475.00 million in debt to four PRC financial leasing companies 
(FLCs) for clean bus leasing since 2013.5 It has also provided $75.00 million for health care 
leasing and $60.00 million for small and medium-sized enterprise lease finance.6 In 2018, ADB 
approved a $150.00 million loan to an FLC to support health care finance in underdeveloped 
provinces in the PRC.7 In 2019, ADB approved a $60 million loan to an FLC to support industrial 
and municipal wastewater treatment.8 This project builds on ADB’s earlier experience in the 
PRC’s leasing industry, using lease finance to support a new sector. Leasing is an attractive and 
effective financing modality for solar equipment as its long-term amortizing repayment profile 
better matches the lessee’s operating cash flows. ADB identified CFL as a good partner to support 
solar power financing given CFL’s focus on solar energy and experience in financing SPPs. CFL 
has strong shareholders, sound corporate governance, an experienced management team, 
advanced risk management systems, and good financial performance. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
7.  CFL was established in March 2015 as the only wholly owned subsidiary of the China Citic 
Bank (CNCB) and is regulated by the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission 
(CBIRC). By 30 June 2019, CFL had total assets of CNY49.70 billion, with outstanding gross 
lease receivables of CNY49.01 billion. Its registered capital is CNY4.00 billion. As a relatively 
young leasing company, CFL has had a specialization strategy since its establishment. Its 
business focus is on green leasing, covering clean energy, energy savings, environmental 
protection, and modern transportation. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
 
8.  CFL receives good support from CNCB in terms of management systems, brand value, 
liquidity  support,  and  business  development.  CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION  DELETED. 
Senior management is mainly from the parent bank and has extensive credit expertise. According

C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance  
 
9.  Ownership. CNCB, a national joint-stock commercial bank in the PRC, was set up in 1987 
and has been listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 
2007. As of 30 June 2019, CNCB had total assets of CNY6,398.80 billion. It is rated BBB+ by 
Standard & Poor’s, Baa2 by Moody’s Investors Service, and BBB by Fitch Ratings. As of 
June 2019, CNCB’s three largest shareholders were Citic Corporation Limited with a 65.37% 
share, China Tobacco Corporation with 4.39%, and China Security Finance Corporation Limited 
with 2.28%. Citic Corporation Limited is a wholly owned subsidiary of Citic Limited, which is 
58.13% owned by CITIC Group Corporation Ltd., which is in turn 100.00% owned by the PRC 
State Council. China Tobacco and China Security Finance are also 100.00% owned by the PRC 
State Council.10 Therefore, the Government of the PRC is CNCB’s largest ultimate shareholder, 
holding about 45% of total shares. Integrity due diligence was conducted.11 No significant or 
potentially  significant  risks  were  identified.  Although  CFL’s  beneficial  owners  could  not  be 
identified, the potential risk is mitigated by the fact that CNCB’s relevant shares are held by public 
and institutional investors, and no shareholder other than the government holds more than a 5% 
indirect stake in CFL. ADB’s review of the entity does not give ADB cause to believe that it is 
being used for money laundering or terrorism financing. Tax integrity due diligence was not 
required because the transaction does not involve intermediate jurisdictions or material related 
party transactions.12 
 
10.  Management. CFL is led by an experienced management team comprising the chief 
executive officer (CEO) and four vice-presidents, four of whom held senior positions at CNCB 
before joining CFL. CEO Yu Ziyan has a master’s degree and is a senior chartered economist 
with more than 30 years of experience working in economics and finance. He was the deputy 
general manager and chief risk officer at CNCB’s Suzhou branch, deputy general manager of 
CNCB’s Kunshan branch, general manager of the credit department of the Shanghai Pudong 
Development  Bank’s  Suzhou  branch,  and  deputy  general  manager  of  the  Bank  of 
Communications’ Suzhou branch.13 
 
11.  Governance structure. CFL has a well-defined corporate governance structure. The 
board of directors handles CFL’s overall strategy, major decisions, key business objectives, and 
senior management appointments. The board has six members, all appointed by the parent bank. 
The composition of the board is typical for companies with only one shareholder. The chair, 
Yang Yu,  has  a  doctorate  in  business  administration  and  is  a  senior  chartered  economist 
accredited  in  the  PRC.  He  has  36  years  of  experience  working  in  finance.  Yang  serves 
concurrently as CNCB deputy general manager. Before joining CNCB, he held senior positions

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
12.  ADB will provide a senior secured loan to CFL of up to $70 million (or its yuan equivalent) 
with a tenor of up to 5 years. 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  Use of proceeds. CFL will use the proceeds of the ADB loan to finance the development 
and operation of SPPs for solar energy generation in the PRC. At least four SPPs will be financed, 
with each subproject receiving no more than $17.50 million of the ADB loan proceeds. 
 
14.  Legal documentation. The loan to CFL will be governed by a facility agreement, which 
will be based on ADB’s customary terms and conditions for a loan of this nature and amount. 
 
15.  Reporting arrangements. ADB will carry out project monitoring over the life of the project. 
CFL will provide ADB with financial and other reports at predetermined regular intervals and as 
requested, including (i) semiannual unaudited financial statements, (ii) annual audited financial 
statements,  (iii) compliance  certificates  for financial  covenants,  (iv)  periodic  reports  on  the 
underlying leases financed through the proposed loan, (v) annual reports on the implementation 
status of the environmental and social management system (ESMS), and (vi) annual reporting on 
selected development indicators agreed by ADB and the borrower. 
 
16.  Evaluation. ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department will prepare monitoring reports 
and submit them to ADB’s Office of Risk Management regularly and at least annually. The first 
report will be submitted no later than 12 months after the first disbursement. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
17.  Providing critically needed long-term finance. The PRC’s leasing industry is still in the 
early stages of development. Most funding is available to companies at 1-year tenor. As noted in 
para. 15, CFL has a significant maturity mismatch between its assets and liabilities. Long-tenor 
funding of 5 years from ADB will help support CFL’s long-tenor financing for SPPs, with typical 
lease terms of 5–10 years, thereby contributing to the improvement of CFL’s asset–liability profile. 
This, in turn, will increase CFL’s capacity to expand operations and address its funding gap. 
 
18.  Enhancing Citic Financial Leasing Co. Ltd.’s environmental and social safeguard 
capacity and supporting gender equity. ADB will be the first international financial institution to 
provide financing to CFL. As a disbursement condition, CFL must establish an ESMS that meets 
the requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). ADB will continue to work with

5 
CFL throughout the ADB investment period to enhance CFL’s safeguard capacity, support its 
adherence to high safeguard standards, and promote gender-inclusive measures in operations. 
CFL will appoint a gender champion to empower and help create opportunities for CFL’s female 
staff, including mentorship and leadership training.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
19.  Impacts. The project is expected to have the following development impacts: 
(i)  Renewable energy generation capacity increased. By financing SPPs, the 
project  will  help  increase  solar  power  capacity,  thus  supporting  the  PRC’s 
commitment in its intended nationally determined contribution under the Paris 
Agreement to peak its carbon emissions by 2030 and to increase non-fossil fuel 
energy to 20% of its energy mix. 
(ii)  Financial leasing industry developed. Despite rapid growth since 2008, the 
PRC’s financial leasing industry is still underdeveloped, with a  lower leasing 
penetration rate than other developed markets. Access to finance remains a 
challenge for most leasing companies, particularly for long-tenor loans, and the 
project will help alleviate this funding bottleneck. 
 
20.  Outcome. The outcome will be development of solar energy projects. XX megawatts of 
solar energy generation capacity will be installed, which is expected to generate about XX 
megawatt-hours of electricity per year and lead to a GHG emissions reduction of about XX tons 
of carbon dioxide per year over the 5-year life of the ADB loan. 
 
21.  Outputs. The outputs will be the following: 
(i)  Citic Financial Leasing Co. Ltd.’s solar energy lease operations expanded. 
CFL will provide an additional $70 million in lease finance to at least four SPPs. 
(ii)  Citic Financial Leasing Co. Ltd.’s gender inclusiveness improved. The project 
will strengthen CFL’s gender inclusiveness in operations by providing mentorship 
and leadership training programs to female staff and internship programs to female 
students. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
22.  Consistency  with  ADB  strategy  and  country  strategy.  The  project  supports 
Strategy 2030’s operational priority of tackling climate change, building climate and disaster 
resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability.14 Under Strategy 2030, ADB will increase 
its emphasis on assisting developing member countries in improving environmental management, 
including efforts to foster green economic growth. ADB will scale up support for climate change 
mitigation by prioritizing investments for low GHG emission energy and provide $80 billion of 
cumulative  climate  finance  from  ADB’s  own  resources  from  2019  to  2030.  The  project  is 
consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the PRC as it will support the 
 
14 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

6 
government’s reform agenda to manage climate change and the environment, and to finance 
private sector-led initiatives to support climate change mitigation and adaptation.15 
 
23.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project aligns 
with ADB’s Energy Policy, which states that support for renewable energy projects will be 
prioritized and broadened, and private sector participation will be encouraged.16 Supporting 
finance sector development is a key focus of development assistance for ADB, and the project 
aligns with ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan.17 Client selection and project design reflect 
ADB’s experience in the PRC leasing industry by selecting financial intermediaries that have 
proven expertise in the targeted sector, and augmenting the design by leveraging the expertise 
of sector specialists and gender specialists in the early stages of structuring transactions. Lastly, 
the project is aligned with ADB’s Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Operational Plan, 
2013–2020.18 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
24.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement as category FI for the environment and involuntary resettlement, and category FI 
treated as C for indigenous peoples.19 
 
25.  Category FI. ADB has assessed the investment’s potential environmental and social 
(E&S) impacts; its risks associated with CFL’s existing and likely future portfolio; and its policies, 
procedures,  commitment,  and  capacity  for  E&S  management.  During  due  diligence,  ADB 
determined that CFL’s financial leasing for the development and operation of SPPs in the PRC is 
considered low to moderate risk and is expected to have limited and localized E&S impacts. 
Potential environmental impacts mainly involve temporary environmental, health, and safety 
impacts during project construction; environmental, health, and safety impacts associated with 
solar panel cleaning wastewater effluent discharge; power safety; fire prevention; disposal of 
waste solar panels; and occupational health and safety exposures. These are considered less 
adverse and site-specific, few or none are irreversible, and the few impacts can be readily 
addressed by mitigation measures. As the proposed project is for equipment leasing, the climate 
change impact risk is expected to be low. Solar energy generation can support climate change 
mitigation by reducing GHG emissions from fossil fuel. CFL’s financial leasing to SPPs is not 
expected to involve significant involuntary resettlement impacts as solar farms are primarily sited 
on leased lands, and procuring small parcels of land will only be needed for substations and/or 
office control rooms that will require permanent construction. CFL ensures that solar project lands 
are procured and/or leased and compensated following applicable laws on a willing buyer or 
lessee–willing seller or lessor basis, and the processes are already completed by the government 
and relevant village committee before CFL’s financing. CFL’s portfolio includes lease financing of 
solar power projects in areas with the presence of ethnic minority groups; SPPs in these areas 
are normally built on leased wastelands and are unlikely to entail impacts relating to physical or 
economic displacements and/or indigenous peoples or ethnic minorities.

26.  CFL will adopt an ESMS satisfactory to ADB before the first disbursement. The ESMS will 
include an E&S policy, procedures for investment screening against ADB’s prohibited investment 
activities list; project E&S risks and impacts review and categorization; procedures for screening 
funding for projects in environmentally and socially sensitive areas or critical habitats; an audit of 
the land acquisition history, including impacts on vulnerable and non-titled land users; due 
diligence on occupational health and safety issues; investment documentation; project E&S 
management, monitoring, and reporting; E&S organization and capacity building; stakeholder 
engagement; meaningful consultation; and grievance redress mechanisms. CFL will exclude from 
ADB financing solar power projects with significant impacts on the environment and involuntary 
resettlement and any adverse impacts on indigenous peoples. It will ensure that investments 
using ADB funds abide by applicable national laws and regulations and comply with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. CFL will appoint a designated E&S staff member to lead ESMS 
implementation. 
 
27.  Labor and social protection. CFL employs 95 staff and ensures the well-being of its 
workforce by following the provisions stated in the PRC’s Labor Law, 1995 and Labor Contract 
Law, 2008. CFL’s lease approval process includes the review of labor contracts and research on 
labor noncompliance records or labor issues lodged within the government or courts related to 
the potential subproject. CFL complies with and will ensure the compliance of solar power lease 
financing projects with national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy, take 
measures to comply with internationally recognized core labor standards.20 CFL will report 
regularly to ADB on (i) its compliance with such laws and (ii) the measures taken. Information 
disclosure and consultation with affected people will be conducted following ADB requirements. 
 
28.  Some gender elements. CFL is an equal opportunity employer and has expressed strict 
compliance  with the  PRC  Law  on the  Protection  of  Rights  and Interest  of Women,  2005. 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. CFL commits to implement measures to promote 
gender equality and/or women’s empowerment in its business activities following ADB’s Policy on 
Gender and Development (1998). Through the project, CFL will strengthen the provision of 
training to female staff, which includes (i) mentorship and leadership training programs, and (ii) 
internship programs for female students in finance or other relevant subjects. CFL will submit 
periodic reports on the implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
29.  CFL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.

C.  Assurances 
 
30.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),21 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the

VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
31.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$70,000,000 (or its yuan equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Citic Financial 
Leasing Co. Ltd. for the Solar Energy Finance Project in the People’s Republic of China, with 
such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, 
and as may be reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject: The project entails the Asian Development Bank (ADB) providing long-tenor financing to Citic Financial Leasing (CFL) for lease finance to solar power plants (SPPs) for solar energy generation in the PRC. ADB financing will meet CFL’s requirements for long-term funding, which is in short supply in the PRC, and will enable CFL to provide long-tenor lease finance to SPPs.
